title: Agile Product Owner in 16 minutes
description: This video created by Henrik Kniberg is one of the best ever made in describing the role of the product owner in an agile setting. It's clear and very well produced and leaves you with great visual notes to use as a basis for discussions with your team if you watch it together.
author: Henrik Kniberg

title: The trap of iterative waterfall
description: How an organization can be fooled to think they are agile but are really using an "iterative waterfall" method
author: Mike Cohn

title: 78 Things I've Learned 9 Years Agile Coaching
description: A very nice list to read through every now and then that reminds you of some basics.
author: Jean Tabaka

title: Scrum Checklist
description: Here's a checklist that has some good pointers to what scrum is.
author: Henrik Kniberg

title: Agile Meetings Cube
description: Pdf to print and create a physical cube with one scrum ceremony per side.

title: Scrum Guide
description: The official scrum guide from the founders of scrum
author: Ken Schwaber and Jeff Sutherland

title: Online scrum assessment
description: Test your scrum skills online

title: Scrum Roles Mindmap
description: A mindmap of different roles and their responsabilities in scrum.
author: Mattias Skarin

title: Product Owner Role Mindmap
description: A mindmap of things that are included in the product owner role.

title: Retrospectives Wiki
description: A list of retrospectives in a wiki-styled page

title: Visual "Jimmy Cards"
description: Jimmy Cards are aids in having retrospectives or for building knowledge
author: Jimmy JanlÃ©n

title: What's in a user story?
description: A great blog entry about what user stories are and what should be put into them. How should they be written and what information is important?
author: Dan North

title: Splitting User Stories
description: This article gives some tips and tricks about splitting user stories.
author: Richard Lawrence

title: INVEST in User Stories and create SMART tasks
description: This article talks about how to create good user stories and tasks using the INVEST and SMART acronyms
author: William Wake

title: Searching in TFS
description: Tips and tricks when searching in FTS web portal

title: 7P framwork
description: The 7P framwork is a good tool to use when planning meetings. It allows you to think about your meetings in advance and to have better meetings.

title: Continuous Delivery Maturity Model
description: This article talks about how an organization can be agile on different levels. There is a great image that summarizes the maturity model in a matrix.

title: Video about Estimating
description: This video has some good stuff in it. It's not the best but it will give you some arguments when talking about the benefits of agile over waterfall.

title: Short Video about Working Agreements
description: This video talks about working agreements in a short and conscise way.

title: Draw a Toast
description: The exercise "How to Draw a Toast" is a great exercise to show the benefits of collaborating as a group with sticky notes. The site also has other nice stuff.

title: Hyper Island Toolbox
description: Hyper Island is a school. They have a site with short games that you can use for different teams.

title: Gamestorming site
description: There is a book called Gamestorming with lots of exercises you can use for different purposes with teams. This is the site that goes with it. Most games can be found here if you know what you are looking for.

title: Agile Manifesto
description: The agile manifesto is used as a definition of agile in software development. It was created back in 2001 when a group of now more or less famous people met to discuss new trends in software development. It is seen as an important document in the agile community.

title: User story map
description: A user story map is a powerful tool for visualizing progress in a project. The concept was developed by Jeff Patton who has written a great book about the concept but this presentation is a great introduction and gives a good overview of how a user story map can be created.
author: Steve Rogalsky

title: How to Implement Hypothesis Driven Development
description: Another take on how to break development into incremental pieces. While user stories put the user, action and purpose in focus the central concept of hypothesis driven development is the desired outcome and how to measure that.
author: Barry O'Reilly

title: User stories and backlog management slides
description: Great slides from a workshop regarding user stories. Talks about requirements and why user stories are such a big deal. Also talks about backlog management and requirements in a more modern software development.
author: Peter Antman

title: App for simple johari window
description: This site is an app allowing for the creation of a johari window. Johari window is a tool that can be used to better understanding yourself and the perception of you by others.

title: Impact mapping
description: "Why do you want this product?" This is a great article describing the concept of impact mapping and how it can be used to make and visualize roadmap decisions based on the result you want to achieve.
author: Dominic Krimmer

title: Helium stick exercise
description: Helium stick is a great exercise for teams to get them to discuss communication and roles in a the team. The link provided is probably as good as searching for "Helium stick".

title: Introduction to behaviour-driven development (BDD)
description: BDD is Dan North's concept that descibes as a better way of descibing test-driven development (TDD) in a way that gets more straight to the good stuff and avoids the pitfalls.
author: Dan North

title: Technology Radar
description: Technology radar is a website created by the company ThoughtWorks. The site which is update bi-annually rates different techniques, tools, platforms, languages and framworks on a scale from 'adopt' to 'hold'. It's a great tool for starting discussions and keeping track of the multitude of changes in this field.
author: ThoughtWorks

title: The State of JavaScript
description: This site gives a structure to the chaos and mess in the JavaScript world. What tools are used, which are liked, ...

title: A3 thinking
description: This presentation introduces a bunch of great values related to agile, organization and management organization as well as the tool 'A3' for getting to the root of problems and eventually solving them. The presentation also contains an introction to 'POPCORN' flow for accelerating continuous improvements. Slides 8, 9, and 20 are some of my favourites when it comes to discussion management in software development, agile adoption and self-organizing teams.
author: Claudio Perrone

title: POPCORN Flow
description: These slides introduces the concept of POPCORN Flow. It's an acronym used to describe the different states of a kanban setup for creating small and rapid experiments for continuous improvements or continuous evolution as Claudio Perrone would put it.
author: Claudio Perrone

title: The resource utilization trap
description: In this video Henrik Kniberg makes a very visual demonstration of the problem with resource optimization and how a pull system can be used to move towards flow optimization.
author: Henrik Kniberg

title: Blink Estimations
description: In this article Dan North describes his thoughts on estimations and how very simple exercises can create very accurate estimates if done correctly and how they could replace long and detailed estimations without loosing accuracy.
author: Dan North

title: Post Mortem Template
description: A template for having a post mortem briefing for incidents, discussing what happened and actions to take.

title: Software Inventory
description: Joel on Software describes the cost of grooming and working with backlog items that will never be build and the cost of having 'inventory' in the workflow. This article contains some great arguments that can be used when discussing process with a team, managers or product owners.
author: Joel Spolsky

title: 12 Manager READMEs from Silicon Valleyâ€™s Top Tech Companies
description: This post links to several documents written by development/engineering managers at different companies who define how they work, what they do, what they value and how to interact with them. Reading this is great for reflection. When reading them it's good to know differences in work culture to the US.

title: Support your managers with these re:Work tools
description: re:Work is google sharing their internal tools and thoughts for managers. Some of these are great input and tools for reflecting on your manager style.

title: The happy secret to better work
description: In this video we get a few tips on how to be happier through a few steps. 1. Three gratitudes. 2. Journaling 3. Exercise 4. Meditation 5. Random acts of kindness.
author: Shawn Achor

title: What is a scrum master?
description: A nice article even if not using scrum. It raises thoughts regarding the interaction between the team, the product owner and the scrum master. It talks about what the scrum master does and no matter what you think of what it says and what a scrum master should do or not it's a good place for discussions within a team on who does what.
author: Max Rahkopf

title: CS50
description: CS50 is a harvard course intro to developement. It has several different courses that goes into different specifics and all videos are available on youtube.

title: Developer Roadmap
description: This document describes tools, techniques and technologies for different kinds of web developers (front-end, back-end and DevOps) that might be useful or 'required'. I like to use this as something to use as a basis for discussions in a variety of scenarios.

title: Interactive git cheat sheet
description: This site is an interactive cheat sheet for git which shows visually and interactively how different git commands are used and where.

title: Programming exercises, code katas and puzzles for your job interview training - or just for fun.
description: This repo contains a long list of coding exercises that could potentially be used in interviews or other fun exercise scenarios.

title: Links related to engineering management
description: A collection of inspiring resources related to engineering management and tech leadership. Quite a big more extensive than this list. Very inspirational

title: Links related to development
description: A collection of full-stack resources for programmers. By same the author as the link above.

title: Create a retrospective
description: A simple tool for creating a retrospecive exercise in the five stage process (set the stage, gather data, generate insights, decide what to do).
